I kept hearing about tony robbins so I watched the documentary about him on Netflix, part of me really liked the idea but afterwards I sat back and thought about it.. 
He tends to use what I would call an abusive tactic in which he makes you get deep and personal and take action, even forcing people to do things they might not want to do with the pressure of him and a huge crowd urging them to do so.. he also has been known to trigger people as he is very vulgar and aggressive at times which is the part I find abusive.. he uses terms like â€œbitchâ€ and claims itâ€™s to get your attention but in reality you shouldnâ€™t be getting put down like that in order to hear someone. 
I think itâ€™s quite ridiculous that they make the crowd dance and â€œget excitedâ€ before tony arrives... why? And yes I believe many people go because they are mentally unstable, because they are struggling and everyone is different.. everyone has different history and experience and vulnerabilities and the way he expects everyone to have endless energy like you mention having a sixteen hour day is not fair or realistic. I know for me one of my biggest issues is managing my energy levels as I struggle with depression and bipolar as well.. and some days doing nothing is exhausting for my body.. forcing me into a state of that kind would not in any way benefit me as it would cause extreme exhaustion and make me feel mentally drained. 
I also do think he definitely uses this to his advantage of selling things. Why the fuck is it so expensive to listen to some guy talk? Itâ€™s insane! But he does get people in a sort of trance and they feel good in the moment so they believe it will help them and again like you said even the mantras he used itâ€™s almost brainwashing.. he keeps telling you to take action and stay pumped and of course your going to buy another seminar.. I donâ€™t agree with what he does at all. 
And no I donâ€™t think your stupid or judge you at all for any of this! Itâ€™s intended to do exactly what it did to you. And many others have fallen for t, to be honest I would have too if I hadnâ€™t watched the documentary and even after watching I wanted to go see him speak but I didint have money so I couldnâ€™t which gave me time to think about it all and come to a different conclusion on him.

My brother is transitioning (weâ€™re in Canada) and heâ€™s very lucky to have it covered! It costs thousands and thousands of dollars. Iâ€™ve seen him psychologically distressed by body image and how much it impacted him. He was constantly embarrassed-and didnâ€™t feel his true gender prior to top surgery. Every time he looked in the mirror he beat himself up over it.. I always tried to help him find clothes to help â€œhideâ€ his top but thereâ€™s only so much you can do..  this created so much anxiety and frustration as well as fed into his depression as people would mis gender him often. 
He now has had top surgery and he is way more confident and smiles much more. His mental state is in such a better place. 
To me people have insecurities of not liking there nose or wanting a boob job which I know is difficult to live with, and at the same time we all have things we donâ€™t like about our body.. but gender issues is much more psychological. And yes many people who are transgender also have to live in fear during transition if they havenâ€™t had surgeries and it is noticeable they are transgender there life is in danger.. thatâ€™s cruel and unfair. 
Itâ€™s much more then making someone comfortable. Itâ€™s safety, itâ€™s reduction of suicide itâ€™s acceptance and equality and keeping humans safe for being who they are.

They are similar. Psychotherapy is more based just on talking where as CBT is a lot of using diagrams itâ€™s commonly known as a â€œhomework therapyâ€ the sheets help you notice thought patterns/ reactions etc. 

Iâ€™m not 100% sure though!

Basically they read through a list of things so they should mention that if you state you plan to harm yourself or someone else they have a duty to report it.. 
that being said therapists will talk to you about it and see where you are at.. if it is ideation they can help you with coping etc.. if you state that â€œI am going to kill myselfâ€ or that you have a set plan to do so is when they have a duty to report. 
I was terrified to talk to my therapists about this in the past but I now know that they wonâ€™t automatically report it. They  canâ€™t let you leave if they feel or know that you will act on it. As they have a duty to keep you safe. 

A HELPFUL SIDE NOTE: you can talk to them in hypotheticals as for example 
â€œHypothetically if someone were to mention they feel suicidal what would happen?â€ 
Or 
â€œI have a friend who is worried about mentioning to there therapist they are suicidal, what would happen in that situationâ€ 
This way they can answer and if you donâ€™t feel comfortable continuing the conversation about yourself you donâ€™t have too. A lot of people will do this. They canâ€™t report it in this case because you havenâ€™t said itâ€™s about you.
